articles.title: A (Literal) Passport Out of Russia: Give Birth in Argentina
articles.description: Since the Ukraine war, pregnant Russians have been flocking to the South American country where obtaining citizenship is relatively easy — if your child is born there.
articles.content: What began as a trickle has exploded in popularity, according to Argentine migration officials. About 4,500 Russians arrived in January, four times as many as last January, though it is not clear how many were pregnant women. Two major hospitals in B... [1306 chars]

articles.title: A (literal) passport out of Russia: give birth in Argentina
articles.description: Since the Kremlin’s invasion of Ukraine, thousands of Russians have arrived in Argentina with a baby on the way, lured by the country’s relatively easy and speedy path to a passport that will give their children and them more freedom than their Russian passports.
articles.content:
She was sent to join several other pregnant Russians in a common area of the airport, where they dragged furniture together and cracked jokes to calm their nerves.
Among them was Maria Konovalova, who was pulled aside and asked about her pregnancy. S... [7823 chars]

articles.title: Argentina grains exchange cuts forecast for soybean, corn production
articles.description: BUENOS AIRES, March 9 (Reuters) - Argentina's soybean production for the 2022/2023 harvesting season is estimated at 29 million tonnes, down from 33.5 million tonnes previously estimated, the Buenos Aires grains exchange said on Thursday.The exchange also cut its estimate for 2022/23 corn production to 37.5 million tonnes, down from the 41 million tonnes previously expected.
articles.content:
BUENOS AIRES, March 9 (Reuters) - Argentina's soybean production for the 2022/2023 harvesting season is estimated at 29 million tonnes, down from 33.5 million tonnes previously estimated, the Buenos Aires grains exchange said on Thursday.

articles.title: In homeland of Pope Francis, long absence prompts prayers for return
articles.description: In the Buenos Aires shanty town area of Villa 21-24, Justina Ayala, 72, remembers the day Pope Francis left Argentina for the Vatican 10 years ago. He has not been back to his homeland - struggling with debt, economic crisis and poverty - since.
articles.content:
[1/4] Catholic faithfuls pray during a mass at the Basilica San Jose de Flores, where Pope Francis used to attend in his childhood, in Buenos Aires, Argentina March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Agustin Marcarian

articles.title: The Lionel Messi project has failed at PSG - and nobody really cares
articles.description: Argentina's World Cup winner added glamour to an already star-studded project, but we won't remember his performances for the French club
articles.content:
When signing for Paris Saint-Germain, you have to accept that the success or failure of your season is decided in a couple of matches in the spring. Wrapping up the Ligue 1 title is considered a formality. It’s really all about the Champions League.

articles.title: Jill Biden calls on men to support women fighting for rights
articles.description: The group includes the first female general to serve in the Mongolian armed forces, along with advocates for protecting indigenous lands in Costa Rica and ending discrimination against people with disabilities in Malaysia and against LGBTQ people in Argentina.

articles.title: Latin America And Caribbean Passenger Traffic Recovery Slows Slightly In January
articles.description: Argentina had a full domestic traffic recovery for the first time since the pandemic began.
articles.content: The recovery of the Latin American & Caribbean aviation industry has faced a setback, according to the Latin American & Caribbean Air Transport Association (ALTA). About 31.3 million passengers were carried during January in the region, 3.6% below pr... [3127 chars]
